sections.title: Introduction
sections.content: Welcome to Unit 17 of our English learning journey. In this unit, we'll explore the use of 'have' and 'have got'

sections.title: Definition
sections.content: to express possession and other related meanings. Let's delve into the key concepts.

sections.title: Have Formation
points: They have a meeting at 3 PM

sections.title: 'Have' Formation
points: I have got a new laptop
He has got a beautiful garden.

sections.title: Usage
sections.content: Understand when to use 'have' and 'have got' based on possession and context.
points: 'Have' is commonly used in American English
'Have got' is more common in British English.

sections.title: Examples
sections.content: Let's examine examples to illustrate the application of 'have' and 'have got'

examples.Positive: I have a cat, and she has got a dog
examples.Negative: We have a picnic every Sunday
examples.Interrogative: She has got a headache today

sections.title: Exercise - Possession Comparison
sections.content: Write sentences comparing possession using both 'have' and 'have got' For example:
points: I have a bike, but my brother has got a motorcycle.

sections.title: Common Mistakes
sections.content: Address common mistakes related to the use of 'have' and 'have got'
points: Incorrect:I have got a meeting yesterday.
Correct: I had a meeting yesterday

sections.title: Recap and Summary:
sections.content: In summary, 'have' and 'have got' are used to express possession and related meanings. Pay attention to the context and regional variations in usage.

sections.title: Additional Resources:
sections.content: For additional practice and reinforcement, consider exploring examples in language learning books and online exercises.

sections.title: Conclusion
sections.content: Thank you for joining today's lesson on 'Have and Have Got' Practice using both forms to express possession, and feel free to reach out if you have any questions. Happy learning!
